map.string: OSCAL Plan of Action and Milestones (POA&M) Format: JSON Schema
A partition or component of a control or part
A unique identifier for a specific part instance. This identifier's uniqueness is document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same part across minor revisions of the document.
A textual label that uniquely identifies the part's semantic type.
A namespace qualifying the part's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the part's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple parts of the same control with the same name and ns.
A name given to the part, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.
Permits multiple paragraphs, lists, tables etc.
Parameters provide a mechanism for the dynamic assignment of value(s) in a control.
A unique identifier for a specific parameter instance. This identifier's uniqueness is document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same parameter across minor revisions of the document.
A textual label that provides a characterization of the parameter.
A short, placeholder name for the parameter, which can be used as a subsitute for a value if no value is assigned.
Describes the purpose and use of a parameter
A formal or informal expression of a constraint or test
A textual summary of the constraint to be applied.
A formal (executable) expression of a constraint
A prose statement that provides a recommendation for the use of a parameter.
Prose permits multiple paragraphs, lists, tables etc.
A parameter value or set of values.
Describes the number of selections that must occur.
A value selection among several such options
Provides information about the publication and availability of the containing document.
A name given to the document, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.
The date and time the document was published. The date-time value must be formatted according to RFC 3339 with full time and time zone included.
The date and time the document was last modified. The date-time value must be formatted according to RFC 3339 with full time and time zone included.
A string used to distinguish the current version of the document from other previous (and future) versions.
The OSCAL model version the document was authored against.
An entry in a sequential list of revisions to the containing document in reverse chronological order (i.e., most recent previous revision first).
A name given to the document revision, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.
The date and time the document was published. The date-time value must be formatted according to RFC 3339 with full time and time zone included.
The date and time the document was last modified. The date-time value must be formatted according to RFC 3339 with full time and time zone included.
A string used to distinguish the current version of the document from other previous (and future) versions.
The OSCAL model version the document was authored against.
A document identifier qualified by an identifier type.
Qualifies the kind of document identifier.
A location, with associated metadata that can be referenced.
A unique identifier that can be used to reference this defined location elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given location across revisions of the document.
A name given to the location, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.
A postal address for the location.
A single line of an address.
City, town or geographical region for the mailing address.
State, province or analogous geographical region for mailing address
Postal or ZIP code for mailing address
The ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code for the mailing address.
An email address as defined by RFC 5322 Section 3.4.1.
Indicates the type of phone number.
The uniform resource locator (URL) for a web site or Internet presence associated with the location.
References a location defined in metadata.
A responsible entity which is either a person or an organization.
A unique identifier that can be used to reference this defined location elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given party across revisions of the document.
A category describing the kind of party the object describes.
The full name of the party. This is typically the legal name associated with the party.
A short common name, abbreviation, or acronym for the party.
An identifier for a person or organization using a designated scheme. e.g. an Open Researcher and Contributor ID (ORCID)
Indicates the type of external identifier.
An email address as defined by RFC 5322 Section 3.4.1.
Indicates the type of phone number.
A postal address for the location.
A single line of an address.
City, town or geographical region for the mailing address.
State, province or analogous geographical region for mailing address
Postal or ZIP code for mailing address
The ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code for the mailing address.
References a location defined in metadata.
Identifies that the party object is a member of the organization associated with the provided UUID.
References a party defined in metadata.
Defines a function assumed or expected to be assumed by a party in a specific situation.
A unique identifier for a specific role instance. This identifier's uniqueness is document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same role across minor revisions of the document.
A name given to the role, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.
A short common name, abbreviation, or acronym for the role.
A summary of the role's purpose and associated responsibilities.
A reference to the roles served by the user.
A collection of resources, which may be included directly or by reference.
A resource associated with content in the containing document. A resource may be directly included in the document base64 encoded or may point to one or more equavalent internet resources.

A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this defined resource elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.
A name given to the resource, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.
A short summary of the resource used to indicate the purpose of the resource.
A document identifier qualified by an identifier type.
Qualifies the kind of document identifier.
A citation consisting of end note text and optional structured bibliographic data.
A container for structured bibliographic information. The model of this information is undefined by OSCAL.
A pointer to an external resource with an optional hash for verification and change detection.
A resolvable URI reference to a resource.
Specifies a media type as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Media Types Registry.
The Base64 alphabet in RFC 2045 - aligned with XSD.
Name of the file before it was encoded as Base64 to be embedded in a resource. This is the name that will be assigned to the file when the file is decoded.
Specifies a media type as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Media Types Registry.

An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which may be expressed as a list of values in some OSCAL formats.
A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given location across revisions of the document.
A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or quality of the property's containing object.
A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns.

An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace qualified name/value pair with optional explanatory remarks. The value of an annotated property is a simple scalar value.
A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or quality of the annotated property's containing object.
A unique identifier that can be used to reference this annotated property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given location across revisions of the document.
A namespace qualifying the annotated property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.
Indicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.
A reference to a local or remote resource
A resolvable URL reference to a resource.
Describes the type of relationship provided by the link. This can be an indicator of the link's purpose.
Specifies a media type as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Media Types Registry.
A textual label to associate with the link, which may be used for presentation in a tool.
A reference to a set of organizations or persons that have responsibility for performing a referenced role in the context of the containing object.
A representation of a cryptographic digest generated over a resource using a specified hash algorithm.
Method by which a hash is derived
Additional commentary on the containing object.
Describes which specific statements are addressed by a requirement, by pointing to a specific requirement statement within a control.
A reference to one or more roles with responsibility for performing a function relative to the containing object.
Identifies the parameter that will be set by the enclosed value.
A parameter value or set of values.
A system security plan, such as those described in NIST SP 800-18
System Security Plan Universally Unique Identifier
A globally unique identifier for this catalog instance. This UUID should be changed when this document is revised.
Used to import the OSCAL profile representing the system's control baseline.
A resolvable URL reference to the profile to use as the system's control baseline.
Contains the characteristics of the system, such as its name, purpose, and security impact level.
A unique identifier for the system described by this system security plan.
Identifies the identification system from which the provided identifier was assigned.
The full name of the system.
A short name for the system, such as an acronym, that is suitable for display in a data table or summary list.
The overall information system sensitivity categorization, such as defined by FIPS-199.
Contains details about all information types that are stored, processed, or transmitted by the system, such as privacy information, and those defined in NIST SP 800-60.
Contains details about one information type that is stored, processed, or transmitted by the system, such as privacy information, and those defined in NIST SP 800-60.

A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this information type entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.
A human readable name for the information type. This title should be meaningful within the context of the system.
A summary of how this information type is used within the system.
An identifier qualified by the given identification system used, such as NIST SP 800-60.
The expected level of impact resulting from the unauthorized disclosure of information.
The expected level of impact resulting from the unauthorized modification of information.
The expected level of impact resulting from the disruption of access to or use of information or the information system.
The prescribed base (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.
The selected (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.
If the selected security level is different from the base security level, this contains the justification for the change.
The overall level of expected impact resulting from unauthorized disclosure, modification, or loss of access to information.
A target-level of confidentiality for the system, based on the sensitivity of information within the system.
A target-level of integrity for the system, based on the sensitivity of information within the system.
A target-level of availability for the system, based on the sensitivity of information within the system.
Describes the operational status of the system.
A description of another authorized system from which this system inherits capabilities that satisfy security requirements. Another term for this concept is a common control provider.

A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this leveraged authorization entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.
A human readable name for the leveraged authorization in the context of the system.
A reference to the party that manages the leveraged system.
The date this system received its authorization.
A description of this system's authorization boundary, optionally supplemented by diagrams that illustrate the authorization boundary.
A summary of the system's authorization boundary.
Commentary about the system's authorization boundary that enhances the diagram.
A graphic that provides a visual representation the system, or some aspect of it.
Commentary about the diagram that enhances it.
A brief caption to annotate the diagram.
A description of the system's network architecture, optionally supplemented by diagrams that illustrate the network architecture.
A summary of the system's network architecture.
A description of the logical flow of information within the system and across its boundaries, optionally supplemented by diagrams that illustrate these flows.
A summary of the system's data flow.
Provides information as to how the system is implemented.
A type of user that interacts with the system based on an associated role.
A name given to the user, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.
A short common name, abbreviation, or acronym for the user.
A summary of the user's purpose within the system.
Identifies a specific system privilege held by the user, along with an associated description and/or rationale for the privilege.
A human readable name for the privilege.
A summary of the privilege's purpose within the system.
Describes a function performed for a given authorized privilege by this user class.
A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.
A category describing the purpose of the component.
A human readable name for the system component.
A description of the component, including information about its function.
A summary of the technological or business purpose of the component.
Describes the operational status of the system component.
A reference to one or more roles with responsibility for performing a function relative to the control.
Information about the protocol used to provide a service.
A human readable name for the protocol (e.g., Transport Layer Security).
Where applicable this is the IPv4 port range on which the service operates.
Indicates the starting port number in a port range
Indicates the ending port number in a port range
A set of inventory-item entries that represent the managed inventory instances of the system.
A single managed inventory item within the system.
Organizational asset identifier that is unique in the context of the system. This may be a reference to the identifier used in an asset tracking system or a vulnerability scanning tool.
A name/value pair with optional explanatory remarks.
Indicates the value of the characteristic.
Specifies a media type as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Media Types Registry.
A reference to a set of organizations or persons that have responsibility for performing a referenced role relative to the parent context.
The set of componenets that are implemented in a given system inventory item.
A name/value pair with optional explanatory remarks.
Indicates the value of the characteristic.
Specifies a media type as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Media Types Registry.
A reference to a set of organizations or persons that have responsibility for performing a referenced role relative to the parent context.
Describes how the system satisfies a set of controls.
Describes how the system satisfies an individual control.
A reference to a control identifier.
A reference to one or more roles with responsibility for performing a function relative to the control.
Identifies which statements within a control are addressed.
A reference to one or more roles with responsibility for performing a function relative to the control.
Defines how the referenced component implements a set of controls.
A reference to one or more roles with responsibility for performing a function relative to the control.
Identifies content intended for external consumption, such as with leveraged organizations.
Describes a capability which may be inherited by a leveraging system.
Describes a responsibiity imposed on a leveraging system.
Identifies a 'provided' assembly associated with this assembly.
Describes a responsibiity imposed on a leveraging system.
Identifies a 'provided' assembly associated with this assembly.
Describes how this system satisfies a responsibiity imposed by a leveraged system.
Identifies a 'provided' assembly associated with this assembly.
NOT TO BE USED FOR A BASE METASCHEMA ONLY FOR A MODULE
Used by the assessment plan and POA&M to import information about the system.
>A resolvable URL reference to the system security plan for the system being assessed.

Identifies the controls being assessed and their control objectives. In the assessment plans, these are the planned controls and objectives. In the assessment results, these are the actual controls and objectives, reflecting any changes from the plan.
A human-readable description of control objectives.
Identifies the controls being assessed. In the assessment plan, these are the planned controls. In the assessment results, these are the actual controls, and reflects any changes from the plan.
A human-readable description of in-scope controls specified for assessment.
Identifies an individual control to include.
A reference to a control identifier.
Identifies an individual control to exclude.
A reference to a control identifier.

Identifies the control objectives of the assessment. In the assessment plan, these are the planned objectives. In the assessment results, these are the actual objectives, and reflects any changes from the plan.
A human-readable description of this collection of control objectives.
Identifies an individual control objective to include.
Identifies an individual control objective to exclude.
A local definition of a control objective for this assessment. Uses catalog syntax for control objective and assessment actions.

A unique identifier for the assessment-specific control objective instance. This identifier's uniqueness is document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same role across minor revisions of the document.
A reference to a control identifier.
A human-readable description of this control objective.
Identifies a method for assessing the satisfaction of this objective.
Identifies the assessment method by its UUID value.
A local definition of a control objective. Uses catalog syntax for control objective and assessment actions.

Uniquely identifies this defined assessment method. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given assessment method across revisions of the document.
A human-readable description of this assessment method.
Identifies exactly what will be the focus of this assessment. Anything not explicitly defined is out-of-scope.

A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the include-subject. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple include-subjects of the same ns.
A human-readable description of the collection of subjects being included in this assessment.

Identifies what is explicitly excluded from this assessment. Used to remove a subset of items from groups of explicitly included items. Also used to explicitly clarify off-limit items, such as hosts to avoid scanning.

A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the exclude-subject. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple exclude-subjects of the same ns.
A human-readable description of the collection of subjects being excluded from this assessment.
A pointer to a resource based on its ID. Use type to indicate whether the identified resource is a component, inventory item, location, user, or something else.
A pointer to a component, inventory-item, location, party, user, or resource using it's UUID.
The title or name for the referenced subject.
A key word to indicate all
Identifies the assets used to perform this assessment, such as the assessment team, scanning tools, and assumptions.

The technology tools used by the assessor to perform the assessment, such as vulnerability scanners. In the assessment plan these are the intended tools. In the assessment results, these are the actual tools used, including any differences from the assessment plan.
Identifies the origination of network-based assessment activities, such as the IP address of the tool performing assessment scans.
The title or name for this assessment origination item.
A human-readable description of assessment originiation asset.
Properties of this asset, which is used to perform the assessment.

Uniquely identifies this defined property. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given property across revisions of the document.
A textual label that identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or quality of the property's containing object.
A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns.
Identifies the assessment activities and schedule. In the assessment plan, these are planned activities. In the assessment results, these are the actual activities performed.

Uniquely identifies this defined test method. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given test method across revisions of the document.
The title or name for this test method.
A human-readable description of this test method and collection of test steps.

Typically used in when copying content from the assessment plan to the assessment results. The uuid should be changed in the assessment results file, and the compare-to field should be set to the original assessment plan uuid value. This enables the plan and results to be compared later to identify what changed between the two.

Uniquely identifies this defined test step. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given test step across revisions of the document.
A human-readable description of this test step.
Identifies the sequence number for the test step.
Identifies the schedule for the assessment activities.

Uniquely identifies this schedule. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for this schedule across revisions of the document.

Uniquely identifies this defined task. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given task across revisions of the document.
A human-readable description of this task.
Identifies roles associated with performing this task.
Identifies people or organizations associated with performing this task.
Identifies locations associated with performing this task.
Identifies the start of a task.
Identifies the end of a task.
Links the task to a defined activity.
Identifies an assessment activity. In the assessment plan, this is an intended/in-scope activity. In the assessment results, this identifies an activity that was actually performed.

Uniquely identifies this included activity. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given included activity across revisions of the document.
The title for this included activity.
A human-readable description of this included activity.
Identifies roles associated with performing this activity.
Identifies people or organizations associated with performing this activity.
Identifies locations associated with performing this activity.

Identifies an activity explicitly excluded from the assessment. In the assessment plan, this clarifies activities that are out-of-scope or prohibited. In the assessment results, this could be used to explicitly identify an activity that was planned, but not performed.

Uniquely identifies this excluded activity. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given excluded activity across revisions of the document.
The title for this excluded activity.
A human-readable description of this excluded activity.
Identifies roles associated with this activity exclusion.
Identifies people or organizations associated with this activity exclusion.
Identifies locations associated with this activity exclusion.

Used by the assessment results and POA&M. In the assessment results, this identifies all of the assessment observations and findings, initial and residual risks, deviations, and disposition. In the POA&M, this identifies initial and residual risks, deviations, and disposition.

Uniquely identifies this set of results. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. Once assigned, a UUID should be consistantly used for a given set of results across revisions.
The title for this set of results.
A human-readable description of this set of test results.
Date/time stamp identifying the start of the evidence collection reflected in these results.
Date/time stamp identifying the end of the evidence collection reflected in these results. In a continuous motoring scenario, this may contain the same value as start if appropriate.

Uniquely identifies this finding. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. Once assigned, a UUID should be consistantly used for a given finding across revisions.
A human-readable description of this finding.
Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.
Date/time stamp identifying when the finding information was collected.
Date/time identifying when the finding information is out-of-date and no longer valid. Typically used with continuous assessment scenarios.
The person who collected the evidence or made the observation.
Identifies the implementation statement in the SSP to which this finding is related.
Date/time stamp of the associated information.
Date/time stamp identifying when the information was collected.
Date/time identifying when the information expires. Typically used with continuous assessment scenarios.
Captures an assessor's conclusions regarding the degree to which an objective is satisfied.
A reference to a control identifier.
The title for this objective status.
A human-readable description of the assessor's conclusions regarding the degree to which an objective is satisfied.
A brief indication as to whether the objective is satisfied or not.
Identifies the framework or rules to which this value conforms.
Identifies the implementation status of the control or control objective.
Identifies the framework or rules to which this value conforms.

Uniquely identifies this observation. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. Once assigned, a UUID should be consistantly used for a given observation across revisions.
A human-readable description of this assessment observation.
Identifies the source of the finding, such as a tool, interviewed person, or activity.
A pointer to a relevant item, using it's UUID.
Links this observation to relevant evidence.
>A resolvable URL reference to relevant evidence.
A human-readable description of this evidence.
Identifies an individual who gathered the evidence resulting in the observation or risk identification.
The UUID of the assessor who collected the evidence or made the observation.
Identifies the tool or activity that resulted in the observation.
A pointer to a relevant item, using it's UUID.
Identifies how the observation was made.
Identifies the nature of the observation. More than one may be used to further qualify and enable filtering.
A pointer, by ID, to an externally-defined threat.
Specifies the source of the threat information.
An optional location for the threat data, from which this ID originates.

Uniquely identifies this risk. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. Once assigned, a UUID should be consistantly used for a given risk across revisions.
A human-readable description of this risk.
The date/time by which the risk must be closed.
An individual risk metric from a specified system.
Specifies the system represented by this risk metric.
A log of events and actions taken towards the remediation of the associated risk.
Individual remediation tracking entry, which logs an event or action taken towards the remediation of the associated risk.

Uniquely identifies this tracking entry. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. Once assigned, a UUID should be consistantly used for a given tracking entry across revisions.
The title for this tracking entry.
A human-readable description of this tracking entry.
Identifies an asset required to achieve remediation.

Uniquely identifies this required asset. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. Once assigned, a UUID should be consistantly used for a given required asset across revisions.
The title for this required asset.
A human-readable description of this required asset.
Describes the status of the associated risk.
Describes the actions taken that resulted in the closure of the identified risk.
Describes a mitigating factor with an optional link to an implementation statement in the SSP.

Uniquely identifies this mitigating factor. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. Once assigned, a UUID should be consistantly used for a given mitigating factor across revisions.
Points to an implementation statement in the SSP.
A human-readable description of this mitigating factor.
Describes either recommendation or an actual plan for remediating the risk.

Uniquely identifies this remediation. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. Once assigned, a UUID should be consistantly used for a given remediation across revisions.
The title for this remediation activity.
A human-readable description of this remediation plan.
Points to the source of the recommendation
A pointer to a relevant item, using it's UUID.
Points to the source of the remediation recommendation or plan
A pointer to a relevant item, using it's UUID.
A partition or component of an objective or part
A unique identifier for a specific part instance. This identifier's uniqueness is document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same part across minor revisions of the document.
A textual label that uniquely identifies the part's semantic type.
A namespace qualifying the part's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the part's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple parts of the same control with the same name and ns.
A name given to the part, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.
Permits multiple paragraphs, lists, tables etc.
A plan of action and milestones, such as those required by FedRAMP.
Uniquely identifies this POA&M. This UUID must be changed each time the content of the POA&M changes.
Allows components, and inventory-items to be defined within the POA&M for circumstances where no OSCAL-based SSP exists, or is not delivered with the POA&M.
This identifies initial and residual risks, deviations, and disposition.
The title this collection of POA&M items.
A human-readable description of this collection of POA&M items.
Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.
A textual label that identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or quality of the property's containing object.
POA&M Items Property Universally Unique Identifier

Uniquely identifies the property of this collection of POA&M items. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given property across revisions of the document.
A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns.
Date/time stamp identifying the start of the evidence collection reflected in these results.
Date/time stamp identifying the end of the evidence collection reflected in these results. In a continuous monitoring scenario, this may be omitted or contain the same value as start if appropriate.

Uniquely identifies the POA&M entry. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given POA&M item across revisions of the document.
The title or name for this POA&M item .
A human-readable description of POA&M item.
Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.
POA&M Item Property Universally Unique Identifier

Uniquely identifies the property of this POA&M item. This UUID may be referenced elsewhere in an OSCAL document when refering to this information. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given property across revisions of the document.
A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns.
Date/time stamp identifying when the finding information was collected.
Date/time identifying when the finding information is out-of-date and no longer valid. Typically used with continuous assessment scenarios.
The person who collected the evidence or made the observation.
